intro: Spermacoce casmae, commonly known as the Andean moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andes region of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes coffee and gardenias, and is characterized by its showy, white flowers that open at night. The plant produces small, spherical fruits that contain numerous seeds, typical of the genus Spermacoce. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in mountainous regions with rich soil. Due to its unique blooming pattern and ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens.
